ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed my precision and skills in writing philosophical papers, and broadened my knowledge on the topic of dualism and the role of mind and personal identity in our day to day life.

Learned to think critically about various problems in philosophy of mind both in the early modern period and in contemporary thought, including but not limited to: personal identity, emergence, dualism, perception, to name a few.
I got a deeper understanding of the philosophy of mind and perception. I also got a good overview of the historical and current dialogue about these topics.
I learnt to close read philosophical texts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I found the material towards the latter half of the semester on perception to be a bit less engaging and interesting than the material in the first half of the semester. The personal identity discussions were, in my opinion, more lively than our discussions on perception and sight and the related material.

The reading list is really great, the course is well-run, and the material in-class is covered extensively.
A general problem with philosophy seminars is that graduate students tend to (over)run the class. Although less true of this one, I still did feel like certain students dominated the conversation, and it was a bit harder to participate.

Strength - the readings were great, and the topics are very interesting. Feedback on papers was incredibly detailed and thoughtful.
Weakness - the class conversation was pretty uneven. Almost 75% of the class never said a single word. I think the professors could have made more effort to make the environment more inclusive of everyone.

This was a really intellectually demanding and interesting course, and both profs have been incredibly attentive, generous and thorough. I did feel sometimes the conversation in seminar was dominated by a few people -- a challenge that can be hard to overcome when the readings can be quite daunting at times.
Seminar handouts were excellent. Prof Winkler and Ehli are well-prepared for seminars and lead discussions well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes-- professors Ken and Bridger were fantastic, very accessible, and explained the material in an engaging and fun way. I do feel that I learned a lot.
If you are interested in the subject, absolutely! Both Prof. Winkler and Bridger are amazing instructors and I learned so much over the semester.
Yes, the readings were very interesting!
